clinical_study.brief_title: Postoperative Telehealth Mindfulness Intervention After Spine Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: "Optimizing a Postoperative Telehealth Mindfulness Intervention to Improve Pain-related Outcomes and Reduce Opioid Use After Spine Surgery."

brief_summary.textblock: Lumbar spine pain is the leading cause of years lived with a disability and affects over 50 million individuals in the United States. Rates of spine surgeries performed to address degenerative spine conditions have increased markedly. A subset of patients experience poor pain, functional, or quality of life outcomes after surgery. This study will develop, pilot, and evaluate the feasibility and potential benefits of a one-on-one live, telehealth, mindfulness intervention in patients following their lumbar spine surgery. The aim of the intervention is to improve pain management, reduce the need for long-term pain medications, and improve physical and psychological well-being after surgery.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Single-group, mixed methods, repeated measures design

primary_outcome.description: Proportion of participants enrolled who complete the study
Average number of sessions attended out of 8 (proportion)

secondary_outcome.description: One item assessing how bothersome pain has been in the past 7 days from not at all to extremely. A lower scores indicates lower pain bothersomeness.

Pain Interference short-form 4a from the Patient Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System scale. Measures interference of pain in day to day activities, work around the home, participation in social activities, and household chores over the past 7 days. A lower score indicates lower pain interference, or a better outcome.

1 item from the Patient Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS), with average pain intensity over the past 7 days rated on 0-10 scale with lower values indicating less pain, or better outcome.

2 items assessing back and leg pain intensity on a scale of 0-10 over the past 7 days, described as pain when off medication or medication has worn off. Lower scores indicate less pain, or better outcome.
Measured as average number of opioid pills per day (name and dose specified) and converted to morphine equivalent dose.

Anxiety short-form 4a - Patient Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System. 4 items assessing anxiety symptoms in the past 7 days (e.g. "I felt fearful"). Lower scores represent lower anxiety, a better outcome.

Depression short-form 4a - Patient Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System scale. 4 items assessing depressive symptoms over the past 7 days (e.g. "I felt worthless). A lower score indicates less depression, a better outcome.
Assesses impact of pain on level of functioning in 10 areas (e.g. walking, sleep, social life). Lower scores indicate lower level of disability due to pain, a better outcome.
13 items assessing thoughts and feelings when in pain (e.g. "I become afraid that the pain will get worse." Lower scores indicate lower pain catastrophizing, a better outcome.
10 items assessing confidence in ability to do certain things despite pain (e.g. "I can enjoy things, despite the pain." Higher scores indicate greater pain self-efficacy, a better outcome.

4 items assessing perceived level of stress in the past month (e.g. "In the last month, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?") Lower scores indicate lower perceived stress, a better outcome.
13 items assessing fear of movement (e.g. "I'm afraid that I might injure myself if I exercise." Lower scores indicate lower levels of kinesiophobia, a better outcome.

15 items assessing 5 facets of mindfulness, including observing, describing, acting with awareness, non-judging of inner experience, and non-reactivity to inner experience. Higher scores indicate higher levels of mindfulness, a better outcome.

other_outcome.measure: Opioid medication collected from the Electronic Medical Record
other_outcome.description: Opioid medication use from patient's electronic medical record to cross-reference the self-reported opioid medication use

intervention.description: Participants who enroll and complete lumbar spine surgery will participate in a one-on-one telehealth-delivered (online with audio and video) mindfulness intervention with a trained mindfulness therapist. The intervention is adapted from mindfulness-based cognitive therapy and includes eight, weekly sessions lasting 75 minutes each (except the first session which lasts 90 minutes).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. English-speaking adults (age 18+ years) scheduled for their first lumbar spine surgery for a degenerative condition (spinal stenosis, spondylosis with or without myelopathy, and spondylolisthesis)
2. Radiographic evidence of compression of cauda equina or nerve roots by degenerative changes
3. Presence of back and lower extremity pain persisting for at least 3 months
4. Access to stable internet.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Current/history of a primary psychotic or major thought disorder or hospitalization for reasons related to psychosis
2. Major cognitive disorder
3. Active substance use disorder, with the exception of tobacco use disorder (in past month)
4. History of bipolar disorder or dissociative disorder
5. Current PTSD symptoms (in past month)
6. Having a discectomy procedure and surgery for spinal degeneration secondary to scoliosis or radicular symptoms caused by a prolapsed or sequestered disc will be excluded
